content.description:
The rightmost route, another good one and slightly more difficult than Nervous Itch. Climb up through a rock scar and over a small bulge past the first couple bolts. Continue up and slightly left through the grey rock, making some challenging moves off of bad holds. Continue upwards using the left-facing corner feature on the right and a crack feature on the left, to find yourself under the roof. Work your way up to clip the last bolt, and then find out if you have enough gas left in the tank to pull out the roof to the arete on the right and make the final insecure moves to the chains!




7 bolts

climbs.name: Czech, Please!
climbs.fa: Greg Stokes, Shane Vandewater, Daniel Helm. June 2016

content.description:
Left-hand bolt line and first route at the wall. Technical and thoughtful climbing on sometimes tricky holds characterize the lower half of the route. Around the 4-5th bolt pull up and out to left of the bolts and climb on arete and face on good holds to the top. Variation 5.10 b/c (S.Vandewater 06/16): Instead of using the holds around the arete left of the bolts at the top of the route, climb the face directly past the bolts (shown as dashed line on photo).

The original line at the wall, bolted ground up & on-sight as a group effort.Â 


8 bolts. Rap Ring anchors.

climbs.name: Nervous Itch
climbs.fa: Greg Stokes, Shane Vandewater, Daniel Helm. June 2016

content.description:
Center line of bolts. An excellent climb that increases in quality and difficulty the higher you go. Technique and balance are the keys to success. Engaging climbing through several little crux sections in the middle of the route sets you up to negotiate the final hardest crux past the last bolt pulling around the left-facing side of the roof feature. Awesome! 


8 bolts
The Triangle Wall is a newly developed (2016) sport climbing wall just below the base of the right-hand waterfall at Twin Falls.
